summary: William C. Sturbitts was a CIA employee who served as a Special Assistant for Latin America. His depositions, taken on April 16, 1975, reveal his involvement in Cuban operations and economic warfare from 1964 to 1973. He was questioned about his knowledge of CIA activities related to Cuba, including possible assassination attempts against Fidel Castro and the agency's relationship with individuals like Frank Sturgis. The documents suggest Sturbitts had significant knowledge of CIA's anti-Castro activities during the 1960s and 1970s.
significance: William C. Sturbitts is significant in the JFK assassination context due to his involvement in CIA's Cuban operations and his knowledge of potential assassination attempts against Fidel Castro. His depositions were part of investigations into possible Cuban complicity in the JFK assassination, although the Latin America Division report found no definitive proof of Cuban involvement. His role as a CIA Special Assistant for Latin America during a period of intense anti-Castro activities makes his testimony relevant to understanding the broader context of the assassination.
